output_examples.input: How do I prevent echo in my voice application?
output: Use always-on microphone with browser echo cancellation enabled
Configure getUserMedia with echoCancellation: true, noiseSuppression: true, autoGainControl: true
Keep audio in browser pipeline using HTMLAudioElement for playback
Avoid toggling microphone track or routing audio outside browser
Trust browser AEC - it handles echo cancellation automatically

best_practices: Always use browser echo cancellation with echoCancellation: true in getUserMedia constraints
Keep microphone enabled throughout the entire conversation - never toggle track state
Route all audio through browser pipeline using HTMLAudioElement to maintain AEC
anti_patterns: Toggling microphone track on and off during conversation breaks AEC
Routing audio outside browser via AudioWorklet bypass breaks echo cancellation
Implementing custom echo cancellation reinvents the wheel and causes issues

faq.question: Which browsers support browser echo cancellation?
faq.answer: All major browsers support WebRTC echo cancellation including Chrome, Safari, Firefox, and Edge

faq.question: What is the maximum audio sample rate for voice?
faq.answer: Voice applications typically use 24000 Hz sample rate for optimal quality and performance

faq.question: How do I handle microphone permission errors?
faq.answer: Catch NotAllowedError for permission denials and NotFoundError when no microphone is available

faq.question: Does this skill store audio data?
faq.answer: No, this skill only provides guidance. Actual audio handling depends on your implementation

faq.question: Why is my voice system producing echo?
faq.answer: Echo usually occurs when audio leaves the browser pipeline or echoCancellation is disabled

faq.question: How is this different from other voice implementations?
faq.answer: This follows the industry-standard pattern used by ChatGPT, Zoom, and Google Meet with always-on mic
